content.description:
Grab a high, semi-hidden crimp with your left and the good, high undercling with your right, and step up to higher crimps. 

  The grade is probably height-dependent.
content.location: Start about 5-6 feet right of One Trick Pony.

content.description:
Sit start on right side of face heading up to undercling the fat flake, then the move back left slightly and up along arete and face.   Top out at the high point.   

  It is sort of a one and half star problem.
content.location: This is on the same face as Stick 'em but on the other side.

content.description: Sit start on a good crack and good feet. Move up to the right-facing seem. Move your left hand onto the slopey arete and right high and right, stack your fingers on a small little dimple, and pull up and out.
content.location: From the main tail that comes in from the street, this is on the face facing the trail in group of four blocks by the swamp.

content.description: Stand start the arete that is on the opposite end of the boulder from the problem Early Buzz.
content.location: This is on the tall boulder that's about 15 feet from the swamp.

content.description: Sit start using the same horizontal crack as the problem The force (V7), but head up and right to another obvious crack and follow that to the top. This requires a big move to switch between cracks.
content.location: This is in the main area of boulders not far from the street.  The start is the same as the problem The Force.

content.description: Stand start the steep nose with essentially tiny holds and feet. Make a crux move to the pinch/sloper and a burly topout.
content.location: Near the swamp, this is the steep nose that has a 4 foot egg next to it.

content.description: Stand start the center of the semi-blank face with a decent, left hand sidepull.
content.location: It is on the tall boulder that's about 15 feet from the swamp.

content.description:
Climb the slab on backside of the boulder with Wootie and One Trick Pony, et al. using the left arete if you want.   

  This has likely been climbed before.
content.location: Start 6-7 feet right of the problem Wootie around and just around the arete.

content.description: Start on rail under roof with a good foot. Pop to the lip, slap the bald arete, and move up and left to an easy topout.
content.location: Take trail to Force Boulder, and the trail bends right. Head uphill, and this bloc is on the left in 50 feet ... you can't miss it....

content.description: Sit start matched on a crimp, dyno to a big shelf over the lip, and make a slopey top out.
content.location: This is on the short, steep boulder with a slopey top out.

content.description: Sit start just to the left of a tree stump. Traverse the crack left on crimpy pods, move up to a v-shaped crimp higher on the face, and top out.
content.location: This is on the boulder near the swamp that has an obvious, rising, horizontal finger crack on it.

content.description: Sit start the left arete, and move up to top out as for the problem Early Buzz.
Stand start the tall arete on the backside.
content.location: This is on the tall boulder that's 15-20 feet from the swamp.

content.description: Sit start the far left end arete, and traverse right along the slopey lip using crimps and slopers. A couple of cool campus moves will get you to the good crack and top out.
content.location: This is on the far left arete. Start about 14 feet left of the problem Badass with your left hand on a big, square hold.

content.description:
Blunt Force is a direct version of its neighbor. Start as LÃ¨ Blunt, but after the first move, head slightly to the right and straight up with a difficult lip encounter....

 Do you like mantels?
content.location: Use the same starting rail as for LÃ¨ Blunt.

content.description: Sit start with your right hand on a low sidepull and your left hand on a pinch/sloper/crimp type hold. Move up and top out. Other variations may exist.
content.location: This climbs the arete/face shown in the picture.

content.description: This is one of the best after-work areas on Cape Ann due to having easy and short access and the number of routes in a wide range of difficulties and styles in a tiny area.
